title: How does your brain respond to pain? - Karen D. Davis

multiple-choice.question: What is pain, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A physical sensation that occurs when the body is injured.

options.label: B
options.text: An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage.

options.label: C
options.text: A chemical reaction that occurs in the body when it is under stress.

options.label: D
options.text: A psychological response to a stimulus.

multiple-choice.question: What creates the perceptions of pain, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Special tissue damage-sensing nerve cells called nociceptors.

options.label: B
options.text: Processing work by cells called neurons and glia.

options.label: C
options.text: The superhighway that carries pain information from the spinal cord to the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What determines how much pain a person feels and copes with, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The intensity of the pain signal.

options.label: B
options.text: The character of the pain signal.

options.label: C
options.text: The sensitivity and efficacy of the brain circuits.

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of pain-sensing nerve cells.

multiple-choice.question: Why does it matter that there is variability in our pain brain circuits, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it affects the treatment of pain.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it affects the diagnosis of pain.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it affects the way we respond to pain.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it affects the way we perceive pain.

options.text: A treatment that is tailored to a specific group of people.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Why good leaders make you feel safe - Simon Sinek

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to creating a safe and trusting environment within an organization?

options.label: A
options.text: By following strict rules and protocols.

options.label: B
options.text: By providing opportunities for education and growth.

options.label: C
options.text: By prioritizing the safety and well-being of employees.

options.label: D
options.text: By focusing on short-term gains and profits.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a leader and an authority figure, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: A leader is someone who has authority over others, while an authority figure is someone who is followed.

options.label: B
options.text: A leader is someone who prioritizes the needs of others, while an authority figure prioritizes their own needs.

options.label: C
options.text: A leader is someone who makes choices based on their own interests, while an authority figure makes choices based on the needs of others.

options.label: D
options.text: A leader is someone who has no authority, while an authority figure has all the authority.

multiple-choice.question: What is the story of Captain William Swenson, and what does it illustrate about leadership?

options.label: A
options.text: Captain Swenson was a great leader who sacrificed himself to save others, but his actions were not motivated by a desire to help others.

options.label: B
options.text: Captain Swenson was a great leader who put the safety and well-being of others before his own, and his actions were motivated by a desire to help others.

options.label: C
options.text: Captain Swenson was a great leader who prioritized his own interests over the needs of others, but his actions were still heroic.

options.label: D
options.text: Captain Swenson was not a great leader, but his actions were still heroic.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a company that prioritizes profits over people and a company that prioritizes people over profits, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: A company that prioritizes profits over people is more successful and profitable, while a company that prioritizes people over profits is less successful and profitable.

options.label: B
options.text: A company that prioritizes profits over people is more focused on short-term gains, while a company that prioritizes people over profits is more focused on long-term success.

options.label: C
options.text: A company that prioritizes profits over people is more likely to sacrifice its employees, while a company that prioritizes people over profits is more likely to prioritize the well-being of its employees.

options.label: D
options.text: A company that prioritizes profits over people is more likely to be successful in the long run, while a company that prioritizes people over profits is more likely to fail.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to creating a culture of trust and cooperation within an organization, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: By implementing strict rules and protocols.

options.label: B
options.text: By prioritizing the safety and well-being of employees.

options.label: C
options.text: By focusing on short-term gains and profits.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the needs and concerns of employees.

options.text: The 21st century

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: It is more time-consuming than traditional teaching methods

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: To never say anything that could be hurtful to others.

options.text: To never say anything that couldn't stand as the last thing she ever say.

options.text: The top of the brain

options.label: C
options.text: The hippocampus

options.label: D
options.text: The rear of the brain

options.label: B

title: Grammar's great divide: The Oxford comma - TED-Ed

multiple-choice.question: What is the final comma in a list, placed directly before the main conjunction, such as and, or, or nor, called?

options.label: A
options.text: The Oxford comma

options.label: B
options.text: The serial comma

options.label: C
options.text: The conjunction comma

options.label: D
options.text: The list comma

multiple-choice.question: Which language institution recommends the use of the serial comma in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: The AP Style Book

options.label: B
options.text: The MLA

options.label: C
options.text: The Chicago Style Manual

options.label: D
options.text: The US Government Printing Office

options.label: A
options.text: It takes up too much space

options.label: B
options.text: It creates confusion

options.label: C
options.text: The conjunction is usually enough to denote a separate entity

options.label: D
options.text: It is not grammatically correct

options.label: A
options.text: It should always be used

options.label: B
options.text: It should never be used

options.label: C
options.text: Its use is optional and depends on whether it will help to avoid confusion

options.label: D
options.text: It is a matter of personal preference

options.text: Because it takes up too much space

options.label: B
options.text: Because it creates a run-on sentence

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can make the reader wonder what is included in the list

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not grammatically correct

title: From the top of the food chain down: Rewilding our world - George Monbiot

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why farming has started to retreat from many regions, and trees have started to return?

options.label: A
options.text: Climate change

options.label: B
options.text: Globalization of the market for food

options.label: C
options.text: Increased demand for organic produce

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased use of fertilizers

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the ecosystem in Yellowstone National Park after wolves were reintroduced in 1995?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of deer increased, and vegetation declined.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of deer decreased, and vegetation began to recover.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of beavers decreased, and the number of otters increased.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of wolves decreased, and the number of coyotes increased.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a trophic cascade?

options.label: A
options.text: A change in the weather that affects the entire ecosystem.

options.label: B
options.text: A change at the top of the food chain that tumbles all the way to the bottom, affecting every level.

options.label: C
options.text: A change in the soil that affects only the plants in an ecosystem.

options.label: D
options.text: A change in the water cycle that affects the entire ecosystem.

multiple-choice.question: What is rewilding?

options.label: A
options.text: The process of creating an ideal ecosystem, such as a heath or a rainforest.

options.label: B
options.text: The process of undoing some of the damage we've caused, reestablishing species which have been driven out, and then stepping back.

options.label: C
options.text: The process of pushing people off the land to make way for wildlife.

options.label: D
options.text: The process of creating a new species through genetic engineering.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the benefits of rewilding?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a new species through genetic engineering.

options.label: B
options.text: It pushes people off the land to make way for wildlife.

options.label: C
options.text: It reintroduces rare species called hope, which tells us that ecological change need not always proceed in the same direction.

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a new ecosystem that is completely different from the original one.

title: History vs. Andrew Jackson - James Fester

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main criticisms of President Andrew Jackson's presidency?

options.label: A
options.text: He was too lenient with Native American tribes.

options.label: B
options.text: He was too focused on the Bank of the United States.

options.label: C
options.text: He degraded the office of the presidency and caused financial collapse and wanton cruelty against American Indians.

options.label: D
options.text: He was too slow in making decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the act that forced entire tribes out of their native lands, according to the prosecution?

options.label: A
options.text: The Indian Removal Act

options.label: B
options.text: The Bank Veto Act

options.label: C
options.text: The Trail of Tears Act

options.label: D
options.text: The Jacksonian Act

multiple-choice.question: How did President Jackson respond to criticism that he was responsible for the financial Panic of 1837?

options.label: A
options.text: He admitted his role in the crisis and took responsibility.

options.label: B
options.text: He blamed the British banks for raising interest rates and cutting lending.

options.label: C
options.text: He denied any involvement and shifted the crisis was a natural disaster.

options.label: D
options.text: He claimed it was a conspiracy against him.

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the spoils system, according to President Jackson?

options.label: A
options.text: To give posts to party loyalists and enrich them.

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid profiteering or funny business by rotating in office.

options.label: C
options.text: To promote meritocracy and competence.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the size of the federal government.

options.label: A
options.text: He denied any involvement and blamed President Van Buren.

options.label: B
options.text: He admitted his role and took responsibility.

options.label: C
options.text: He claimed it was a necessary evil to keep the Union together.

options.label: D
options.text: He said it was a different time and he did what he thought was best.
